Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Expanding public access to restricted research data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers in disciplines across the behavioral, social, educational, computational, and life sciences collect data whose sharing can pose significant practical and ethical challenges due to privacy concerns, political risk, cultural sensitivities, legal or policy restrictions, and intellectual property constraints. How should researchers protect data while making access as open as possible, in alignment with the principles of open science? And how should data repositories clearly communicate who has what sort of access in ways that encourage suitable uses? This project will create generalizable models and infrastructure that strike a balance between providing open access to research data and materials while protecting research data. The results will bolster transparent, reproducible, integrative, interdisciplinary and insight-generating research across scientific fields by enhancing an existing research data infrastructure that specializes in sharing sensitive research data with restricted scientific audiences.

The proposed infrastructure builds on Databrary.org, a restricted access data library specializing in storing and sharing video data and documentation. Databrary was co-developed by the PI with support from NSF. The project has two aims: (1) Implement interface and metadata enhancements to the NSF-supported Databrary digital library to make sensitive, restricted-access data maximally discoverable to the widest range of audiences, including users of the NSF Public Access Repository (NSF-PAR), and (2) Ensure that Databrary embodies best practices and shares its innovations widely. The activities associated with these aims will expand access to Databraryâ€™s existing holdings, improve the findability, accessibility, interoperability, and reusability of data shared there, and provide insights and knowledge that should benefit other scholarly communities facing similar challenges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Researchers in multiple disciplines collect data about human behavior whose sharing can pose significant practical and ethical challenges due to privacy concerns, political risk, and cultural sensitivities. The Databrary (databrary.org) data library specializes in storing and sharing video and audio recordings of human behavior and related sensitive and identifiable data. Databrary shares these data securely and ethically through a policy framework that restricts access to researchers who have been authorized by their institutions and only with the permission of research participants. Developed with prior NSF and NIH support, Databrary has grown to encompass more than 160 TB of data, contributed by more than 1,700 researchers from more than 770 institutions across the globe. This project sought to enhance the Databrary system.

With NSF support, the project team evaluated Databrary's interfaces related to sharing or obscuring sensitive and identifiable data and made recommendations for future enhancements. The team built and released free, open source infrastructure (software packages, pipelines, web sites) that provide researchers, funders, and the public information about what information is available on Databrary, who funds it, and how to access it. The team consulted community experts about how to make Databrary's existing data more widely useful for future research and how to enhance the system's current schemes for gathering and sharing metadata. We published these recommendations in an open report that will guide future versions of Databrary.

The results of this project should lead to more widespread reuse of shared data on Databrary and more transparent, reproducible, robust, and rigorous findings about human behavior.

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2023
Modified by: Rick O Gilmore

Developed with prior NSF and NIH support, Databrary has grown to encompass more than 160 TB of data, contributed by more than 1,700 researchers from more than 770 institutions across the globe. This project sought to enhance the Databrary system.
